It gives you an option for a bash script — where we run the command with the variables in the command line.

If you configure the alert rules, and GPCC matches that rule through metrics collection ( collection agent detects out of memory ), then gpcc will use the script and populate it with the variables.
You don’t have to worry about populating the variables — you only have to focus on using them.
GPCC would issue the command LINK=… QUERYID=…,SERVERNAME=...QUERYTEXT=… $MASTER_DATA_DIRECTORY/gpmetrics/send_alert.sh
This looks at all the arguments in the command line and parses them out for the rest of the sample script.

replies.text: @litzell Maybe we should add it in case users ignore the prompt printed at the end of “gpperfmon_install --enable” for restarting GPDB.
Sorry -- in linking this thread, i missed adding the detail that this is against GPCC 6.0, which i believe should not rely on gpperfmon
For GPCC 6.x, gpperfmon_install is no longer needed, though you can still use it. @litzell is updating the doc to make it clear.

Thank you for updating the doc.  However, there is a potential bug explored in the linked thread, where a line needed to be added to pg_hba.conf：https://pivotal.slack.com/archives/C0KMVENFJ/p1574205159078300?thread_ts=1574199916.073200&cid=C0KMVENFJ (edited)

Gpcc picks the master interconnect ip (from gp seg config table) then insert it to pghba.  In multilink master, like gbb, you do need to insert the public ip to hba, so gpcc web, listening on public ip,can access the db.
If you don’t have multi link master, you don’t need to add ip to pghba.
Ahhhhhhh, that makes sense.  Thanks, @Stanley Sung!  We'll have to add that to to our GBB installation docs.

GPCC 6.0 --> GPDB 6.0/6.1
GPCC 6.1 --> GPDB 6.0/6.1/6.2/6.3/6.4
GPCC 6.2(not released) -> GPDB 6.0/6.1/6.2/6.3/6.4/6.5/...
Query monitor works with GPCC 6.1 and GPDB 6.3.
Hao is correct. please always use the latest gpcc 6.x.

posts.text: Using the new GPCC for GP5: ERRORunrecognized configuration parameter "gpcc.metrics_collector_pkt_version"
v4.10 on GPDB 5.27.1
@here any idea what the gpcc.metrics_collector_pkt_version error means and why it is here?
@GreenplumGuru that’s an expected message. You can just ignore it.

It is for detecting which version your metrics collector is, and gpcc will take different actions according to result.
A future release gpdb 5.28.0 will have a different result for that query, so that GPCC can enable some feature for that GPDB. (such as multi GPCC instance per host)

question about gpmetrics.table_info:   we saw some entries in table_info with last_vacuum/last_seq_scan/last_index_scan/…..with null values.   Does this mean those tables have not bee sampled by gpcc?  let’s say the oldest timestamp in those columns are May28/2020. does it mean gpcc started collecting table_info May28/2020.
can we say that those tables with last_seq_scan column null haven’t been touch since May28-2020?
the use case: dell wants to clean up some tables (with last_access/last_vacuum/last_analyzed) older than 30days.
or 90days
as the oldest timestamps in table_info are around May28-2020.  Does this mean those entries in table_info with those columns null are not active since May28-2020?

replies.text: Yes
These fields get updated when GPCC is running. If you confirm GPCC is running since May28-2020 and those fields are null value, then YES, no such activity were detected since May28-2020.

If you want to drop table according to last_seq_scan+last_index_scan, to ensure extra safety, you can confirm other tables in same database have recorded last_seq_scan+last_index_scan throughout the recent month. By doing so, you have confidence that GPCC is running and fields kept updated as expected.

replies.text: your guess is as good as mine.  I do know postgres has a GUC that allows the customer to specify ciphers called ssl_ciphers so maybe adding something like that to gpcc config file would put it on the customer to define what they want.  Do you currently reject any ciphers today within gpcc?
I think there is a TLS version restriction to only accept 1.2 and above. (edited)

TLS handshake starts from client_hello then server offers suites for client to pick. The problem is that DES is a weak algorithm and most security team will want applications NOT to use DES.     So GPCC needs to provide a cipher filter to disable DES (in this case).

apache http, node.js, jetty..alll should provide this cipher filter. I think go/python http server should also provide the same function. gpcc should provide something similar for admin to filter some ciphers.
We will look into it.
this is a weak point of TLS1.2, since server can offer weak ciphers, hacker can take advantage as client to pick weak ciphers to connect to server.   This has been resolved in TLS1.3.
the workaround is what customer security team is asking. Stop providing weak cipher from server side.
Today, Dell IT dba received the same vulnerability report from security team and ask to remove medium level cipher suites from TLS 1.2
I use gpconfig -c ssl_ciphers -v ‘TLSv1.2:!SSLv3:!3DES:!DES:!aNULL:!eNULL’ to turn those off.
also try client_tls_ciphers=normal in pgbouncer.ini.
So far I don’t know how to do the same to GPCC.
GPStream server use go https server and already turn off those DES ciphers.

posts.text: Hello @NingFu ! I have a customer who is wondering how the WLM is collecting "Total Disk I/O" for each query https://gpcc.docs.pivotal.io/4110/topics/ui/workload-management.html would you like to briefly explain?

replies.text: We have a GPCC FAQ doc that has the answer.
https://onevmw-my.sharepoint.com/:w:/r/personal/ningf_vmware_com/_layouts/15/doc2.aspx?so[…]leredirect=true&cid=bc353f33-1fdd-46fa-8661-72c48395ff13
Or you may refer JIRA MPP-30823
thanks Ning! I'll check
So the "Total Disk I/O" is simply calculating by disk_read_bytes + disk_write_bytes ?
Yes. The confusing part is how the values are collected.
I see, thanks Ning

In fact, GPCC reads IO data for a process from Linux kernel. But since postgres may reuse processes to handle different queries, we can not accurately determine how much disk IO that a query consumes. So if a query runs fast and finishes in a short time, its disk IO may be inaccurate.

On the other hand, from the database’s view, it has no idea if data is read from/written to disk or cache. So we can not calculate the real disk I/O from database statistics. That’s why we have to read OS kernel data file.
Thanks for that additional information Ning, I'll have the customer be aware of that as well

posts.text: HiI have a customer with ccdata directory 2.6G only for 2021. Do we have any plans to have some auto removal script for old logs or this is administrator’s responsibility?

replies.text: Are they using the latest version?
If not, please ask them to upgrade. The new version can avoid the situation as much as possible.
We do not have a plan to remove it automatically. Because we don’t know if the users want to keep the data or not. In some cases, the data may be useful for troubleshooting.
Thanks! So the newest version doesn’t generate so many logs?

I would still sugest to have an option to turn on automatic log rotation. We do have it for greenplum, I can’t imagine a need to keep the performance log from previous year. Maybe we can do it optional to turn on and use similar gucs as with greenplum to control it ?

files under ccdata are not logs. They are data files. Usually those files will be removed automatically after gpcc save the data to the tables. But in some cases, due to a bug in the earlier versions, gpcc fails to save the data, hence leave those data files for human intervention.
oh! I understand now. Ok, in that situation the upgrade would be first thing to do and then if they still see it, we would investigate further. thanks!

posts.text: Hello Team, I am part of TO integrations team and we are woking on monitoring the greenplum db, i went through the doc and came to know about gpperfmondb which when enabled via a config will have agents that collects metrics and stores in the table. I want to know more about how gpcc gather the different level metrics like system, query etc, is it also reading from gpperfmon db or is there any doc where i could get that info?

replies.text: Hi, Sudeep, GPCC collects metrics from the database kernel as well as the OS. Generally speaking, there are 2 kinds of metrics: system metrics (CPU/Memory/Disk IO/Disk Space/…), and query performance metrics.
GPCC saves the metrics data to the tables under gpmetrics schema on the
You may find the explanation about those tables from GPCC’s document: (edited)
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Tanzu-Greenplum-Command-Center/6.7/tanzu-greenplum-command-center/GUID-topics-ref-gpmetrics.html

The system metrics data mainly comes from Linux kernel (for example, data files under /proc/ dir). The query metrics data comes from the database kernel, collected by a Greenplum extension, metrics_collector, and sent to GPCC agent via domain socket, and then to the GPCC backend via gRPC. Since GPDB cluster is a distributed system, GPCC agent and the backend do some aggregations and “rebuild” the distributed data from the cluster back to a consolidated data to get a complete view of the cluster or a query, and save the consolidated data to the tables under gpmetrics schema. (edited)
@Sreeni @skandula @Sree FYI, is there any latency for the metrics in gpperfmon, can u share details about it if u have info about it @NingFu?

posts.text:
I'm struggling to figure out how GPCC determines idle sessions and when they can be terminated. We have some users who have sessions terminated after about 90 seconds and others that have been idle for 22+ hrs (according to the Query History/Sessions tab). And both users are in the same RG with a WLM Idle Session rule set up (RM = x and idle time > 12 hrs and NOT idle in transaction).
And does the wlm_short_query_threshold settings have anything to do with the determination? I ask because we don't have it set so it should be 45 seconds (according to the docs) and I have found 2 instances where the session was terminated at around 90 seconds (neither session was idle). However, in both instances I see a BEGIN and 45 seconds later the session terminated.
If it matters, the sessions terminated after 90s or so make heavy use of stored procs. The session I mentioned that has been running idle for 22+ hrs runs a 'SELECT 1' query every 60 secs. (edited)

replies.text: @ruyang is this a known issue?
Perhaps there’s a known issue where a session with a blocked query running was mistakenly identified as an idle session. See GPCC-91. @NingFu
@csylvester Do you know their  GPCC version?

What do you mean by “The session I mentioned that has been running idle for 22+ hrs runs a ‘SELECT 1’ query every 60 secs” — Is the session idle or not? If it runs a query every 60 seconds, is it marked as an idle session in the pg_stat_activity? (edited)
The killed session probably is caused by this JIRA: https://jira-pivotal.atlassian.net/browse/MPP-32725
It happens when the session has a query being blocked.

We are running 6.8.4 and GP 6.23.3. The session listed as Idle in the Sessions tab is a java app. I think it is a setting in the jdbc driver or the driver pool to keep the connection alive. And this session is listed as idle in pg_stat_activity but the query_start and state_change times change every minute when the 'select 1' executes. Which makes sense unless I could catch it running the select and the state goes to active. So this is likely more an user app issue and not on GPCC. But I still wonder where it gets the idle time as 22+ hrs when this session has been running for days. (edited)
The idle time is calculated by GPCC. I remember that it is calculated by “current time” - “the last query finish time seen by gpcc”. Perhaps that is the problem.

posts.text: Hi @NingFu For GP7, one of our release requirements is around Product Globalization. If GPCC has Globalization needs, please let me know so I can connect us with a G11n team member. Also, which version of GPCC will be supported in GP7 for GA?

replies.text: G11n is already supported in gpcc. Currently we do translation by engineers.
GPCC 6.10 will be equal to GPCC 7.0, which is for GP7.
Regarding g11n, gpcc supports Chinese, Japanese and Korean in addition to English.
If other languages are required, then we may need g11n service.
Glad to hear the team does cover multiple languages. Has GPCC ever engaged with VMware’s G11n team for globalization and localization for any release?
I gave them an introduction about our product and how we do g11n. They offered to provide translation service, but so far we do not use it yet.
The main reason is that the volume of translation of each gpcc’s release is small. Usually less than 100 strings. Using external service will be time consuming compared with internal translation.
I mean, the communication overhead will be bigger than the time spent on translations.
I am considering to use the external service when we need to add a new language, if VMware requires.

Usually translation vendors do not have enough context (they only see the messages, not the whole product), so we will have to review their work when they deliver back. If the volume is small, the the time spending on review will be equal to or more than (if something get wrong we need to ask the vendor to fix it) we translate it by ourselves.
But if we want to translate documents, then we may need to use their service.
Good to know. Thanks Ning! @Kris Since GPCC team does globalization internally, do you think we can call the release requirement for G11n an L10n complete for GP7?
